Expectation1: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation1: A few machines are running hotter than normal after missing their last service window.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They face a serious situation that directly tests their commitment to Christian morals
Story:
I stood in the humming factory, sweat beading on my brow as I stared at the row of machines running hotter than they should. I knew they’d missed their last service window, and it was my job to get them cleaned and maintained before something failed. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “We can’t afford any downtime. Just do what you have to do.” But as I opened the panel of the first machine, I noticed a shortcut—one I’d seen others take before. It would get the machines running cooler, at least for now, but it meant bypassing a safety protocol and logging a false maintenance report. 

As a Christian, I’d always tried to live honestly, to do what was right even when no one was watching. The thought of lying on the report twisted my stomach. But the pressure was real—if I didn’t get these machines back online fast, production would halt, and I’d be letting everyone down. My hands trembled as I weighed the expectations: the company needed results, but my faith demanded integrity. I stared at the maintenance log, heart pounding, caught between the demands of my job and the values I held most dear.
